direction.raw_text: . BEGIN TITLE SEQUENCE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An establishing shot of the rundown train station on an overcast morning. There's snow on the station platform. A train arrives and departs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Behind the station, at the top of the hill, lies the St. Cloud's orphanage.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) In other parts of the world, young men of promise leave home to make their fortunes, battle evil, or solve the problems of the world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I was myself such a young man, when I came to save the orphanage in St. Cloud's... many years ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOUD'S - ORPHANAGE - EARLY MORNING A man and woman (COUPLE #1) make their way toward the main entrance of the large brick building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The couple enters the orphanage, where we hear the sound of babies.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Here in St. Cloud's, I have come to understand that promises are rarely kept, that the battle isn't so much against evil as ignorance, and that being successful can't hold a candle to being of *use*.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Nor have I solved the problem I came here to solve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Two nurses, EDNA and ANGELA, chase CHILDREN--a morning routine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The camera goes up the stairs with some of the kids.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Even in the most enlightened times, unwanted babies will manage to be born. That there will always be orphans is simple not a problem to be solved. Here is St. Cloud's, we don't regard the sordid facts of life as problems.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We enter an office where DR. LARCH shows couple #1 their newly adopted son, HOMER, an infant who lies smiling in Dr. Larch's arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We close in on the infant until his face fills the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Larch hands over the infant to the adopting parents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hesitant nods. (They don't look as if they read.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The parents look with pride at their adopted son.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) In truth, we've only had one real problem.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) His name was Homer Wells.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I named him after the Greek writer. You know Homer, of course?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I made his name "Wells" because I could tell he was very deep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) In truth, Nurse Angela named him-- her father *drilled* wells, and "Homer" was one of her family's umpteen cats.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: At the front door, Larch and the nurses wave and call good- bye to Homer, they close the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The same door swings open; it's another night. The same couple is bringing Homer back. There is concern in their faces as Nurse Edna lets them in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch is delivering his benediction to the boys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he turns, he is startled by Nurse Edna, waiting with couple #1 and baby Homer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch looks quickly at Homer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The mother hands over the baby to Larch. Baby Homer lets out a happy squeal as soon as he's in Larch's arms. The parents stare in disbelief.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: "Good night, you Princes of Maine, you Kings of New England!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's something wrong with him! He never makes a sound.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) He didn't cry enough for them, if you can believe it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think we could have a look at someone a little different?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Thus was Homer Wells returned. He was too happy a baby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Angela and Edna call and wave good-bye to a two-year-old Homer, leaving with COUPLE #2. Larch stands on the porch and watches the family head down the hill.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) The second family has an unfortunate gift for getting sounds out of Homer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . COUPLE #2'S HOME - DAY Larch bursts into the home of the second couple and lifts a crying and bruised Homer out of his bed. There is rage in Larch's eyes as he looks at the couple.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) The rumor was true. They beat him. He couldn't stop crying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOUD'S - DAY Larch carries Homer up the orphanage hill.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Here is St. Cloud's, I try to consider, with each rule I make or break, that my first priority is an orphan's future.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The naked belly of a VERY PREGNANT WOMAN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A tiny hand comes in with a stethoscope and puts it on the big belly. Young Homer's head, with the stethoscope around his neck, pops up behind the belly; he closes his eyes as he concentrates on listening to the sounds of the unborn child. Larch stops in the doorway, catching sight of Homer. He smiles faintly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Easier said than done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . COUPLE #3'S HOME - DAY The door opens to a THIRD COUPLE smiling at us, welcoming and embracing a sixteen-year-old Homer. Behind them waits the would-be STEPSISTER--an attractive girl, a little older then Homer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I told the third family to take good care--this was a special boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer and the stepsister are in bed together. The parents burst in on them--the father chasing Homer around and around the bed, the mother beating her daughter, who covers herself with a pillow.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) It was Homer who took too much good care of himself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . COUPLE #3'S HOME - NIGHT From her window, the stepsister watches Homer leave the house carrying his suitcase. Homer looks up at her as he walks to the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's after dawn, but still a little dark, as Homer walks to the orphanage door, suitcase in hand. A HUGELY PREGNANT WOMAN arrives at the same time. They stand awkwardly next to each other, waiting for someone to answer the door. The woman is crying. Homer reaches out and takes her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The woman sniffles; she nods vaguely. The door opens. Nurse Edna lets the woman in and embraces Homer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be frightened. Everyone is nice here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you live here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just belong here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) What could I do with him? He kept coming back!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Larch instructs an older Homer from "Gray's Anatomy." Homer is bored and looks out the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Homer, if you're going to stay at St. Cloud's, I expect you to be of use.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer looks adoringly at Dr. Larch as Larch examines ANOTHER PREGNANT WOMAN. Larch waves Homer over; he places the boy's hand on the woman's abdomen, to feel the fetus kicking.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) But, in failing to withhold love, had I created a true and everlasting orphan? I had been too successful with Homer Wells. I had managed to make the orphanage his *home*.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Larch closes a door quickly behind him (so that Homer doesn't see the ABORTION PATIENT in the O.R.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer assists Larch in delivering a BABY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer carries a white enamel pail to the incinerator. He looks inside the pail; he stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold on Homer's disgusted expression as he stares at the contents of the pail.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) God forgive me. I have *made* an orphan by loving him too much. Homer Wells will belong to St. Cloud's, forever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . FADE OUT. We hear a song playing on an old phonograph.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the song playing on the old phonograph. Dr. Larch is taking ether. He holds the bottle in one hand, the cone over his mouth and nose with the other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : ST. CLOUD'S, MAINE, MARCH 1943. When Larch dozes off, his hand loosens its grip on the cone; the cone falls off his face, and he wakes up. Then he puts the cone back in place, dripping more ether from the bottle to the gauze covering the cone. Pan the dispensary, which also serves as Larch's photo gallery and bedroom apartment. The ether-bed is separated from the room by a hospital curtain (the kind on casters). We see the recording revolving, the glass-encased cabinets of medical supplies, the old photographs of St. Cloud's. Homer enters, he stands uncomfortably, watching Larch for a moment. Then he turns around and walks back into the corridor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer calls out as though he's just coming down the corridor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Larch! Dr. Larch!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Larch wakes up; he shakes off the ether haze. Homer reenters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Larch and Homer leave together.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We've got two new patients, one to deliver.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The *two* doctors walk briskly down the hall, a couple of professionals.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer and Larch split off and disappear into two different operating rooms. As he goes, Homer mumbles to himself, "Of use, of use, of use."
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: First pregnancy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, for both.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sarcastically) I presume you'd prefer handling the delivery.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tiredly; an old topic) All I said was, I don't want to perform abortions. I have no argument with *you* performing them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know *how* to help these women-- how can you not feel *obligated* to help them when they can't get help anywhere else?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One: it's illegal. Two: I didn't ask how to do it--you just showed me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What *else* could I have showed you, Homer? The only thing I can teach you is what I know! In every life, you've got to be of use.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Larch and Angela are preparing the ether for DOROTHY, a not visibly pregnant woman. The sounds of labor across the hall can be heard Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Angela puts the cone over Dorothy's mouth and nose; Larch drips the ether on the cone. A newborn wails in the other O.R. Over.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (holds the cone) Have you ever had ether, Dorothy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Once, when they took out my appendix.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looks for scar) No one's touched your appendix.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whatever it was... the ether made me sick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It won't make you sick this time, Dorothy--not the way I do it, just a drop at a time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't pay for this, you know--I got no money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One day, Dorothy, if you have any money, a donation to the orphanage would be very much appreciated.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only if you can afford it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (holds the ether bottle) Try to think of nothing, Dorothy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer has delivered CARLA. A newborn baby is screaming in Edna's arms. Homer is attending to Carla, who is panting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch pops into the delivery room; he peers at the baby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edna shows the baby to Carla, who stares, then turns away. Larch whispers to Homer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That was good, Carla--that was *perfect*. Everything's fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't wanna see it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't have to see it, dear. Don't worry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't even wanna know what sex it is--don't tell me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We won't tell you, Carla. You're going to be okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your *baby's* going to be okay, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't wanna know!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's a big boy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me see him, for Christ's sake--I wanna see him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you mind having a look at Dorothy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Angela sits with the still-etherized Dorothy while Larch and Homer confer over a basin containing Dorothy's uterus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Angela hands Larch a bottle of brown liquid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch wrinkles his nose at the odor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch wets his finger with the stuff, then touches it to his tongue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Homer turns to leave, Larch stops him; he points to the basin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer stops, annoyed; he picks up the basin and empties the contents into a white enamel pail.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There was no visible wound?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. The fetus was dead. Her uterus was virtually *disintegrating*--my stitches pulled right through the tissue!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mystified) It looks like scurvy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (derisively sarcastic) Scurvy! Ah yes, the curse of the old- time sailor, suffering long periods at sea with no fresh fruits or vegetables. Homer, Dorothy isn't a *sailor*!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's a prostitute, isn't she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Angela) Did you look in her purse?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (frustrated) I looked everywhere else!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's called French Lunar Solution.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not ergot, it's not pituitary extract, it's not oil of rue...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It claims to restore monthly regularity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's obviously an aborticide.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Obviously.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (spits) Christ, it's oil of tansy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you take enough of it, your intestines lose their ability to absorb Vitamin C.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In other words, scurvy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good boy. Good job. And you call yourself "not a doctor"! (to Angela) Keep an eye on her--she's in trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take care of that, will you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is teaching math to some distracted boys and girls in a corner of the dining room. A blackboard on wheels is a mass of numbers. Homer, passing through the dining room with the white enamel pail, attracts the attention of BUSTER, a sixteen-year-old who is picking over a plate of pastries on a table. Buster immediately goes with Homer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer shakes his head, keeps walking. Buster follows. Dr. Larch passes close to Buster. Buster makes a face, disgusted.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'll help you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Buster and Homer tramp through the snow toward the incinerator. Homer still carries the pail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Buster stands watching as Homer empties the pail into the incinerator.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He *sniffs* that ether! I've seen him do it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's because he's too tired to sleep. He has to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He *smells* like he could put you to sleep!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's a doctor, Buster--doctors smell like ether.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: *You're* a doctor, Homer--you don't smell like ether.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm *not* a doctor. I haven't been to medical school--I haven't even been to high school!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you've studied with the old man for *years*!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm *not* a doctor!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, Homer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: With his head inclined to the giant ear of Larch's phonograph, FUZZY--six, thin, and pale and looking remarkably like an embryo--is listening to a recording. He can't hear what Larch and Homer are saying about him as they construct a humidified tent over a small hospital bed on wheels. The humidifier is operated by a car battery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch plucks Fuzzy from in front of the phonograph and zips him into the breathing tent. Fuzzy smiles. As larch leaves, MARY AGNES, a pretty but tough-looking teenager, comes into the dispensary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary Agnes smiles at Homer; then she sticks her tongue out at him. Homer looks at her impassively, but as the moment continues his expression suggests his annoyance. Fuzzy starts to cough; he wheezes as he breathes. Homer leans down; he peers at Fuzzy through a hole by the zipper of the tent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer examines Mary Agnes' tongue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer is not responding to her come-on. He wheels Fuzzy into the hall.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Fuzzy is not uncommon. I tell you, there's something about the premature babies of alcoholic mothers. They seem susceptible to every damn thing that comes along.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't read that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't, either. But you *will*. The morons who write the books should do a little research *here*.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But isn't Fuzzy just... well, underdeveloped?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When *doesn't* he have bronchitis? I wouldn't call his bronchial infections "underdeveloped." Would you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it, Mary Agnes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (garbled because of her tongue) Look!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you bite it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't remember.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dismissively) It looks like you bit it--it'll be all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe I was kissing someone and he bit me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looks at her tongue again) No, you did it yourself. Maybe in your sleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I must have been *dreaming* of kissing someone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Story time, Fuzzy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In the girls' bunk room, Nurse Edna is saying prayers. The girls lie with their palms pressed together on their chests.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: "Oh Lord, support us all the day long..."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOUD'S - THE HILL - NIGHT The building of St. Cloud's is silhouetted against the sky. Carla, the woman we saw deliver the baby, is heading down the hill alone, she sobs, not looking back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...until the shadows lengthen and the evening comes, and the busy world is hushed, and the fever of life is over, and our work is done."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In the bunk room again, with Edna and the girls.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: "Then in Thy mercy grant us save lodging, and holy rest, and peace at the last."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Amen! Amen! Amen!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dr. Larch is reading from Oliver Twist--the death scene of Bill Sike's dog. The boys listen in horror in their beds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer enters; he walks quietly to his bed in the far corner of the room, where he starts to undress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch turns out the lights. From the open doorway to the hall, Larch delivers his nightly benediction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch closes the door, leaving them in the semi-darkness. One young boy runs into Homer's bed, nervously giggling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boys silently agree, Homer among them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: dog, which had lain concealed till now, ran backwards and forwards on the parapet with a dismal howl, and collecting himself for a spring, jumped for the dead man's shoulders."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Missing his aim, he fell into a ditch, turning completely over as he went; and striking his head against a stone, dashed his brains out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good night, you Princes of Maine! You Kings of New England!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in his breathing tent) Why does Dr. Larch *do* tht every night?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (about seven) Maybe to scare us...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (about eleven) No, you jerk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (about nine) Dr. Larch *loves* us!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But why does he do *that*?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He does it because we like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOUD'S - EARLY MORNING The girls, led by Mary Agnes, round a corner of the orphanage, towing a sled piled high with snowballs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They shriek as the boys suddenly surprise them. Buster throws two hard snowballs that hit Mary Agnes and CLARA (eight or nine) before Mary Agnes overwhelms him and repeatedly sticks his head in the snow. Copperfield, terrified of Mary Agnes, escapes. Curly misses, then tips over the sled of snowballs as Clara and the adorable HAZEL (five or six) throw him to the ground. Fuzzy drops his one snowball; he runs aimlessly in circles, coughing, as Nurse Edna explodes from a door of the orphanage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuzzy coughs and wheezes, trying to catch his breath.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Buster is mine. You two get Copperfield and Curly. Nobody touches Fuzzy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop it! No fighting! *Share* the snowballs!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mouth full of snow) They're *our* snowballs! They *stole* them!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They attacked us--just like the Japs!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen to you, Fuzzy! You've been running. You get to the shower!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: comes up the hill. The orphans stop and stare, brushing snow off themselves, struggling to make themselves look presentable. Curly is desperate to look his best. Mary Agnes doesn't bother to pretty herself. She whispers to Clara and Hazel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I know the type--they'll take one of the babies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The children are eating breakfast as the would-be parents walk around the tables, looking over the assembled orphans. Curly works on his table manners; he forks and eats a piece of pancake with elegance. Angela and Edna try to make the couple slow down by the older children, but the couple stop and stare at the adorable Hazel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch and Homer are examining the babies. The doctors are checking the babies' grips, their eyes, ears, and throats. Angela appears in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Angela disappears. Larch looks at the next baby's record (attached to the bed).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer is tired of this game. Larch touches the child's forehead with his index finger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The baby starts to cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer points his finger at the child's forehead like a gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer is writing the name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are interrupted by Copperfield, who comes running from the corridor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wilbur, the adopting couple is waiting in your office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (irritated) Life is waiting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where's the name sheet?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody's named this one yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's my turn!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Henceforth you shall be... Little Dorrit!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He doesn't like it. (looks at the record) He's a boy, That's why.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't a boy be a Dorrit?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You do it then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Henceforth you shall be... Little Wilbur.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not crazy about the "Little..."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, he's just a Wilbur then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We haven't had a Wilbur here in a year or so, have we? We used to have *dozens*!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They picked Hazel! The idiots chose Hazel!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hazel is being fussed over by Edna. Hazel clutches a cardboard suitcase and a tattered rag doll. Mary Agnes, by far the oldest, sits on a bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel cries harder.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: If people want to adopt one of us, they should have to take the oldest first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, Mary Agnes! This is Hazel's special day--don't make her feel sad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hazel's practically the youngest of us. She should be the *last* to leave!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At least Hazel can talk. Usually they take one of the stupid babies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They take the babies so they won't ever have to tell them that they were orphans!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (begins to cry) I'm not a baby!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you cry, Hazel, they'll just send you back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mary Agnes, that's not true!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what they did to me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You *wanted* to come back--that's why you cried. (to Hazel) You can cry if you feel like it, Hazel. You cry as much as you want.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer is in the corridor outside the office, overhearing Larch's lecture to the couple adopting Hazel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It is strictly for our orphans' sake that I destroy any record of their natural mothers. Of course they will, one day, want to know. But orphans, especially, should look forward to their *futures*. Not back to their pasts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer sees Curly standing all alone by a window in the corridor; a suitcase is next to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curly shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer embraces Curly and lifts him up, he grabs the suitcase and continues down the corridor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer disappears into the boys' bunk room carrying Curly and his suitcase, leaving the corridor empty.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, Curly. You going somewhere?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought they might take me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They wanted a girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody ever wants me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're one of the best, Curly--we couldn't let just anyone take you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Larch wouldn't let just anyone take *any* of us!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's true.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody's asked for me, have they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody special enough, Curly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean somebody asked?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only the right people can have you, Curly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Faces in the windows; the orphans watch Hazel walking across the snowy lawn with her new parents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edna (with the girls) gives her good-bye blessing to Hazel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let us be happy for Hazel. Hazel has found a family. Good night, Hazel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good night, Hazel! Good night, Hazel! Good night, Hazel!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The front door opens. The orphans excitedly run outside onto the green lawn, into the warm weather of spring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Angela is singing along with the song on the phonograph, a more romantic song then before, which rouses Larch from his ether. He is grumpy, but she sings the song in his ear and won't give him back the ether cone; he rolls away from her, but she tickles him and bites his ear, coaxing him into a more playful mood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Playfully, she slips out of his embrace.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I was dreaming about you. How beautiful you were!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You weren't dreaming about me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then I wasn't beautiful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were! You *are*! It was fantastic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was just the ether, Wilbur...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer wheels a tray with glasses of water between the beds. A DISTRAUGHT PREGNANT WOMAN stops him by her bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer touches the woman's belly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer cautiously lays his ear against her belly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She holds Homer's head against her belly; she presses his face into her. She shuts her eyes. Homer's eyes stare widely. Dr. Larch stops in the doorway; he watches with concern.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you okay? Can I get you anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No one but me ever put a hand on me, to feel that baby. Don't you want to touch it or put your ear down to it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Put your ear there. Go on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You shouldn't have a baby if there's no one who wants to put his face right there!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stay right there. Right where you are. Stay right here. Right here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOUD'S - TRAIN STATION - DAY Homer at the train station, staring down the empty tracks. Buster is hanging around with him, kicking a rock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer makes no response. As the train approaches, Homer and Buster go sit on a loading cart. They see the distraught woman (no longer pregnant) from Homer's experience of a few nights ago; she is leaving St. Cloud's without her baby, waiting for the approaching train. Her face is a mask. The DISAPPROVING STATIONMASTER gives her a hard look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Buster is ashamed; he knows he's said the wrong thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The slowly moving train has stopped. There are SOLDIERS leaning out the windows. Buster turns to see Mary Agnes walking past the train--she's doing her best to look grown- up, sophisticated. One of the soldiers reaches out and gently tugs on  her hair. Mary Agnes is enraged; she spits at the soldier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary Agnes spits at *all* the soldiers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The soldiers roll up the windows as Mary Agnes improvises some verbal abuse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camera closes on Homer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do you ever think about leaving this place to go find them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean your parents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know who you mean. I think about leaving here, but not to find *them*.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whoever they were, they didn't *do* any of the things parents are supposed to do. Dr. Larch did those things, and Nurse Edna, and Nurse Angela.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. But sometimes I wish I could meet mine, anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What for, Buster? What would you do if you met them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh... I'd like to show them that I can cook, a little.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You cook very well!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And that I can drive a truck!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) Better than I can!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sometimes I want to meet them so I can kill them. Just sometimes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Homer, you know I would never kill anyone--you know I wouldn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think Mary Agnes could kill someone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I doubt it. She's just an...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...emotional girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's she so emotional about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugs) I don't know. She got left here, like the rest of us, didn't she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The orphans are watching King Kong, the part when the giant ape first captures the screaming Fay Wray. Intercut Kong with the orphans' rapt faces. Homer sits near the front, mesmerized by the film. Dr. Larch and Angela sit by the projector; Larch is reading a letter. Fuzzy points to the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: King Kong is undressing Fay Wray in the cave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch shakes the letter in front of Angela.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The film breaks--to huge cries of disappointment from the orphans. Fuzzy coughs and coughs while Larch fumbles with the projector. Angela turns on the light while Larch squints at the broken film. The orphans are chanting, "Kong! Kong!"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer gets up and walks to the projector.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch abruptly lets go of the film.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edna comes in; she speaks to Larch, then quickly leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch turns to Homer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer shifts his weight to the other foot; aggravated; he stands there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer and Larch stare at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer is also trying to avoid a fight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch can't hide his disappointment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is an uneasy peace.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (coughing) He thinks she's his *mother*!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He doesn't think she's his mother, Fuzzy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He does so! He *loves* her!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How could she be his *mother*?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a harsh whisper) They want to replace me! The Board of Trustees wants to *replace* me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispering back) They just want you to hire some new help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some new *things* would be useful. I don't need any "new help."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Homer! I need you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought you took care of this. It always breaks in the same place. It's your splice, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angry) It's *your* splice! You blame me for everything!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Angela, we need a new movie, a new projector, a new typewriter--*that's* what they should replace around here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have a delivery. Imminent, in my estimation...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Homer, would you get this one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's a patient, right? She should see a doctor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to stay calm) Homer, you are a skilled and gifted surgeon. You have near-prefect obstetrical and gynecological procedure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just mean I'd rather fix the movie. Tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. Okay. You splice. I'll deliver.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer is adjusting Fuzzy's breathing tent as the other boys climb into bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch comes in and walks over to Homer and Fuzzy. Larch and Homer exchange a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer sits down with 'David Copperfield.' There is quiet anticipation while Homer readies himself to read.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch continues to adjust Fuzzy's breathing tent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Close on Fuzzy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Larch bends over Fuzzy to fix the breathing apparatus, Fuzzy whispers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Homer... doesn't King Kong think the woman is his *mother*?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh, sure--that's what Kong thinks, all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's why Kong loves her!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought it was my turn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is. I'll get this. You go ahead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reading) "Whether I shall turn out to be the hero of my own life, or whether that station will be held by anybody else, these pages must show."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: was a posthumous child. My father's eyes had closed upon the light of this world six months, when mine opened on it."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispers to Larch) His father's dead, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispering back) That's right, Fuzz.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) (continues reading) "There is something strange to me, even now, in the reflection that he never saw me..."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is *your* father dead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods, whispers) Cirrhosis--it's a disease of the liver.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: *Liver* killed him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: *Alcohol* killed him--he drank himself to death.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But did you know him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Barely. It hardly mattered that I knew him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you know your mother better?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods, still whispers) She's dead now, too. She was a nanny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's a nanny do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She looks after other people's children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you grow up around here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. She was an immigrant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's an immigrant?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Someone not from Maine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOUD'S - NIGHT The orphanage in moonlight. Not a sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOUD'S - MORNING The children are chasing a ball near the incinerator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: GIRL---not one of the orphans--is lying next to the incinerator. Edna kneels by the strange girl, who cringes with fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girl won't speak; when Edna touches the girl's forehead, she pulls back her hand in alarm.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No one's going to hurt you, dear. Have you come to visit us? We have beds, you know. Have you had any breakfast? What's your name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edna is holding the head of the frightened young girl. The girl is feverishly hot and whimpering; she keeps looking at her feet in the stirrups as if she's an animal caught in a trap. Larch and Homer stand on either side of her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girl shakes her head. The pain stabs her again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another stab of pain contorts the girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girl holds her breath while he examines her abdomen; Homer very delicately examines the girl's abdomen, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girl goes rigid as Larch bends into position.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer assists Larch with the speculum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer holds the girl still--she is babbling on and on while Larch is examining her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch, his wild eye peering into the speculum, makes an audible gasp from the shock of what he sees inside the girl. Larch tells Homer to have a look. Larch then whispers something to Edna; she brings the ether bottle and cone quickly. Larch starts putting the cone in place, over the nose and mouth of the frightened girl. Homer bends to the speculum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer stares into the speculum; he closes his eyes. The girl is resisting the ether, but her eyelids flutter closed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer has pulled off his surgical mask. He leans over the scrub sink, splashing cold water on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer, furious, leaves the operating room. Edna lifts the girl's eyelids for Larch so that he can see how well under the ether she is.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Her temperature is a hundred and four.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (very gently) How old are you, dear? Thirteen?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Twelve? Are you twelve, dear? (the girl nods) You have to tell me how long you've been pregnant. (the girl freezes) Three months?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you *four* months pregnant?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispers to Larch) She's at least *five*.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dear child, it won't hurt when I look. I'm just going to *look*.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me: you haven't done something to yourself, have you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It wasn't me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you go to someone else?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He said he was a doctor. I would never have stuck that inside me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stuck *what* inside you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It wasn't me! I would never do no such thing! I wouldn't stick that inside me! It wasn't me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the twelve-year- old) Listen, you've been very brave. I'm going to put you to sleep--you won't feel it anymore. You've been brave enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's a heavy sedation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You *bet* it's a heavy sedation! The fetus is unexpelled, her uterus is punctured, she has acute peritonitis, and there's a foreign object. I think it's a crochet hook.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Homer) If she'd come to you four months ago and asked you for a simple D and C, what would you have decided to do? *Nothing*? *This* is what doing nothing gets you, Homer. It means that someone else is going to do the job--some moron who doesn't know *how*!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish you'd come to *me*, dear child. You should have come to me, instead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer storms down the hall, then stops, pulling off his white coat. Angry, pacing, he kicks at nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOUD'S - GRAVEYARD - EARLY MORNING Buster and Homer are digging the pit. Larch paces by the coffin of the 12-year-old girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Buster nods, but he's totally bewildered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Buster doesn't get it. Homer has heard this too many times; he rolls his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer looks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch studies him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What'd she die of?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (inhales deeply) She died of *secrecy*, she died of *ignorance*...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Homer) If you expect people to be responsible for their children, you have to give them the right to decide whether or not to *have* children. Wouldn't you agree?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How about expecting people to be responsible enough to control themselves to begin with?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How about this child? You expect *her* to be responsible?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't mean her. I'm talking about... adults. (annoyed) You know who I mean!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOUD'S ROAD - TRUCK CAB - DAY Buster is driving the old pickup truck, with the shovels and a wheelbarrow in the back. Larch and Homer are in the cab, they are being bounced all over the cab by Buster's wild driving. Larch looks at Homer; he stares at him with a curious smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch says nothing. Homer gives him a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Buster is distracted; he drives the truck into a ditch and it bounces around, missing a tree by an inch. He is up on the road again in a few seconds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are all distracted by a luxurious convertible that overtakes them on the hill to the orphanage. The fast car is driven by a handsome man in the uniform of the Army Air Corps-- a YOUNG OFFICER. From the passenger seat, a BEAUTIFUL YOUNG WOMAN smiles at them, rendering them speechless.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) It's just a marvel to me that you still have such high expectations of people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm happy I amuse you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Homer) Try to look at it this way. What choice does Buster have? What are his options? Nobody will ever adopt him. (Buster considers this)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Try to look at it *this* way. Buster and I are sitting right here beside you. We could have ended up in the incinerator! (Buster grins)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Happy to be alive, under any circumstances--is that your point?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Happy to be alive... I guess so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The luxurious convertible (now parked) has drawn all the orphans to it. The handsome young officer (WALLY) and the beautiful young woman (CANDY) stand confused by the car; they are surrounded by the curious orphans, with whom they are painfully self-conscious. They are overly friendly to the children as they are anxious of Larch and Homer and Buster (in their gravedigging attire), who are getting out of the truck. Nervously, Wally gives the children chocolates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kids climb into Wally's car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curly tugs on Candy's dress, staring up at her, his face already smeared with chocolate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curly's nose is streaming snot. Candy kneels beside him and holds her handkerchief to his nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curly tries to talk while she's holding his nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other orphans are dying with envy--Candy is so beautiful. (Some, like Buster, are torn between Candy and the car.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Virtually all the orphans have climbed into Wally's car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch, scowling, presents himself to the new couple.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch picks up Curly and carries him toward the boys' division.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So many children. Are they all orphans?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, this *is* an orphanage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, they're getting into the car... watch your fingers!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm the best.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sweetly) You are?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (good with kids) The best? Wow! The best at *what*?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm the best one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here, blow...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I really *am* the best, I just have a cold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Blow! There, I bet that feels better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sniffs) Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Curly, come here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Larch) *Tell* them! I'm the one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Wally) I'm sorry. They're not used to seeing a car like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's okay--I don't mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We brought some chocolates for the kids.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (witheringly) Chocolates. How *thoughtful*.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm the best! *Tell* them!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're the best, Curly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer is seated in the desk chair. The impressive couple sit in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally jumps up to his feet to shake Homer's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally sits down. The three sit still for an awkward moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer writes on a piece of paper. Candy and Wally exchange a worried look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edna pokes her head in the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edna quickly sees that all three of them have misunderstood her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy and Wally can't conceal how impressed they are with the young Homer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So, Mrs...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Candy. Candy Kendall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wally. Wally Worthington.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Candy) How many months are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispers) Two.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, now, uh... you're not... I mean, do *you* do the--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Dr. Larch will be performing the procedure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (relieved) Ah, well... okay. Good! I just wondered...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, Homer. Dr. Larch said this one is your turn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, dear--I'm sorry. I meant the circumcision. That boy you delivered on Tuesday...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. Fine. Have you prepped him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll get started.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer walks down the corridor, dressed in his operating gown, as the door to the O.R. opens and Wally stumbles out, hurriedly opening a window. Wally breathes deeply to regain his composure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edna comes down the hall with a dirt-stained, crying Curly who's covering one eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer nods to Edna, who is marching off with Curly. Wally smiles at Homer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally hears Homer's facetiousness--how tired he is of his heart condition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer appreciates the joke. The door to the operating room that Wally exited opens into the corridor; Candy is being wheeled out on a gurney by Larch and Angela. Wally rushes to Candy's side. Homer follows slowly. Candy is groggy, coming out of the ether.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They walk Candy on her gurney. Homer looks after them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch wheels Candy behind a curtain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch has a different tone of voice when he speaks to Wally.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally is left alone in the corridor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I think it was the ether--the smell got to me. (pause) God. This is all my fault.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (over the din) Steerforth got into the pantry--he's eaten all the pie dough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sobbing) He wasn't sharing it, either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's down the hall, throwing up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What kind of plane are you flying?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Liberator.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Liberator...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you enlisted?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They wouldn't take me. I'm Class IV-- I've got a heart defect.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really! Is it serious?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, it's not serious. I'm just not supposed to get excited. You know-- no strain, no stress. I try to keep calm all the time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, well. I don't imagine there's any strain or stress around *here*!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How is she doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slurred speech) Boy or girl?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was nothing--it's all over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's all over, honey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slurred speech) I would like to have a baby, one day. I really would.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, of course--you can have as many children as you want. I'm sure you'll have very beautiful children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll have Princes of Maine! You'll have Kings of New England!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I suggest you find yourself some fresh air, Lieutenant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Cranked at three-quarters, Fuzzy sits in bed, wheezing and coughing. He's drawing with great intensity, using crayons on a piece of paper held by a clipboard. Homer sits on the end of Fuzzy's bed, cleaning up Steerforth. Homer pauses to look out of the window; he sees Wally, dashing and spotless in his uniform beside his flashy car. A life Homer might have had crosses his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer turns to Fuzzy, who holds up his picture--a big pumpkin with a jack-o-lantern face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer looks at Fuzzy; his little body is working hard just to breathe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuzzy coughs and coughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer looks out the window at Wally again. His decision forms.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Homer, when is Halloween?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (distracted) Uh... it's the end of October.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that soon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's a few months away, Fuzz. (to Homer) I still don't feel so good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (disappointed) Oh. It's the best time! How come we only get pumpkins once a year?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't get too excited, Fuzzy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why can't we have pumpkins for Christmas, too? We don't get any good presents at Christmas, anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer approaches the flashy car, where Wally is still pacing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An awkward silence, which Homer covers by examining the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer nods, but he has no idea where Cape Kenneth is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally nods.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Has anyone offered you anything to eat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Actually, someone did. I just didn't think I could eat anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to sound casual) I wonder if you might give me a ride.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure! Be glad to! Uh... a ride where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (unprepared) Where are you going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're heading back to Cape Kenneth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cape Kenneth...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That sounds fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer runs up the stairs, two steps at a time; he races into a corridor at full speed, exhilarated. Suddenly Dr. Larch appears in front of him. Homer stops abruptly, out of breath, unable to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Homer stands guiltily, Larch rifles through an X-ray file, holding various X rays up to the lit screen. He quickly finds the one he's looking for, attaching it briefly to the screen for a confirming look--a heart X ray, which Larch waves at Homer as he talks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch hands Homer the heart X ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camera closes on Homer with the X ray.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (sarcastic) Doubtless you'll let me know what immensely worthwhile or at least *useful* thing it is that you find to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (restrained) I wasn't intending to leave here in order to be entirely useless--I expect I'll find some ways to be of use.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In other parts of the world, I suppose there are other ways.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still restrained) Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blows up) Are you really so *stupid* that you imagine you're going to find a more gratifying life? What you're going to find is people like the poor people who get left here--only nobody takes care of them as well! And you won't be able to take care of them, either. There's no taking care of *anybody*-- not out there!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (feeling trapped) You know I'm grateful for everything you've done for me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calmly) I don't need your gratitude.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (exasperated) I don't need this--I know all about my condition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's your heart--you ought to take it with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Buster and Mary Agnes are serving the evening meal while Larch rails at Angela and Edna, who are helping Buster and Mary Agnes. The sound of children in the dining hall is intermittent and chaotic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camera closes on Larch, fighting tears.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Going where? Does he have a plan of some kind?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will he be back soon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know! He's just leaving-- (to Angela) you're the one who says he needs to see the world! (to Edna) *That's* what he'll do--he'll see the world!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stunned) He's leaving...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He'll need clothes... some money...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let him try to *make* some money! That's part of "seeing the world," isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) Oh, just stop it! You knew this was going to happen. He's a young man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost breaking) He's still a boy--out in the world, he's still a boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just find him some clothes, Wilbur. He could use some clothes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer is packing his things--we see the heart X ray, and some photos of Larch and Edna and Angela. Larch approaches Homer with a small bundle of clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer is grateful and ashamed. Before he can speak, Edna is there--a wad of bills in her hand. She tries to put the money in his pocket; when he refuses it, she simply puts the money in his open suitcase, stuffing the bills under his clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch and Edna retreat from him, humbly, as if they were his servants.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (gently, almost reverently) I think these will fit you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll need some money--just a little something, until you find a job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Homer puts his stuff in the truck of Wally's car, Angela can't resist touching his face. She is too upset to speak. From a window, Larch is watching the departure. He sees Homer saying goodbye to the children, embracing them. From another window, Fuzzy just stares. (Of course he's coughing.) We see Wally carrying Candy to the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She speaks to Homer, touching his sleeve, like a sleepy person, as Wally puts her gently in the backseat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer gets in the passenger seat beside Wally, who starts the car; suddenly there is Curly. Homer can't look at Curly, who looks betrayed. Edna picks up Curly and carries him to the passenger-side window. Curly is sobbing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can't finish what he has to say. Edna kisses him good- bye. From the window, Larch watches the car leave. Buster, whittling a stick, isn't watching.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (groggy) I'm okay--I can walk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want you to walk--I want to carry you. Should I put the top up? It might get cold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No--keep it down. I want to feel the air.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still groggy) Coming with us? It's always a good idea to have a doctor along for the ride.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have to go, Curly. I'm sorry. (to Edna) I couldn't find Buster. Will you tell him...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: There is quiet as the journey gets underway. Wally keeps glancing at Candy in the rear-view mirror; she seems distant, lost in thought. Homer is taking everything in--the speed, the road, the wind in his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Angela speaks to the boys.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let us be happy for Homer Wells...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In the girls' washroom, in front of the mirror by the row of sinks, Mary Agnes is repeatedly slapping her face. Angela's benediction to the boys plays Over this scene of violent self-abuse. Except for the sound of the slaps. Mary Agnes doesn't make a sound.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Homer Wells has found a family. Good night, Homer!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Good night, Homer!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: On his bed, Larch is taking ether. We hear the refrain from the boys in the bunk room Over.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Good night, Homer! Good night, Homer! Good night, Homer Wells!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The radio is playing. Candy is lying down, her knees drawn up, in the backseat; she appears to be asleep, oblivious to Homer and Wally's conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy's eyes are open but her voice is groggy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer looks back at Candy. Her eyes close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy's eyes snap open and she sits up a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy seems irritated with Wally. Homer tries to engage her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer shakes his head, smiles.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Actually, the Army has given me leave twice. First when my father died, and now I'm on leave to help my mother-- I'm just trying to get her ready for the harvest. She's no farmer. Apples were my dad's business. And with the war on, she's short on pickers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Homer) Wally thinks apples are boring.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Homer) I never said they were boring.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You said, "Apples aren't exactly flying."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, they aren't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I'd probably like the apple business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a little overqualified, aren't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I'm not. I need a job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The only jobs are picking jobs. Picking apples is truly boring.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There! You said it was boring.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, *picking* them is! It's about as exciting as... walking!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is your family in the apple business, too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, but I work there--I like it. My dad's a lobsterman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've never seen a lobster.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've never seen the ocean, either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (amazed) You've never seen the *ocean*?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not funny... that's *serious*.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The car is parked at the side of the road. Wally is half- hidden behind a tree. Candy and Homer are left alone in the car; there's an awkward silence as Homer pretends not to hear Wally's excessive peeing. Suddenly Candy starts to sob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer is a doctor--he's used to postabortion reactions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He doesn't, really. Wally returns. Wally leans over Candy to hug her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy pounds on his chest with her fists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally backs away. Candy sobs uncontrollably.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally signals to Homer to get out of the car. Later, Wally and Homer stand outside the car, overhearing Candy's weeping. Homer is smoking nervously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally looks at Homer, who takes a nervous drag on his cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer looks at Wally; he sees the authority in his eyes. Homer drops his cigarette and puts it out with his foot. They notice that Candy has stopped crying. Wally finds Candy asleep in the backseat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I couldn't have a baby with someone who's leaving me--I didn't know what else to do!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's going to be dropping bombs on Mandalay! They're going to be shooting at him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where's Mandalay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Burma!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't have a baby alone. I don't even know if he's coming back!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Honey, honey... of course I'll come back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't *know*, Wally. You have no *idea*!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stay away from me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (strictly medical) This is all normal. Don't worry. The abortion procedure... it affects you. It's the ether, too. It'll take a little time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't *have* any time. There's a *war*!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's all very normal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ought to cut that shit out--it's terrible for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The lone car on the road. Snatches of war news from the radio are the only sound as the headlights illuminate the dark highway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The car is parked, with Homer sleeping in it alone. The sounds of the ocean increase as Homer opens his eyes. Homer gets out of the car and walks toward the beach, enchanted. There it is: his first view ever of an ocean, the horizon, the sun glimmering on the water. Candy is lying on a blanket in the sand. Wally is throwing rocks in the water. Homer takes it all in. When Candy calls for him, Homer walks up to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A football comes flying through the air toward Homer; it bounces off his chest. Wally laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer throws the football; it's clear he's never thrown one before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer runs over to Wally, who proceeds to show him how to pass the ball. Snatches of his instruction drift to Candy, who closes her eyes. "Put your fingers on the laces--no, it rests in your palm, like this! You want the laces up--yes, like that!"
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a little worried about the... (she gestures below her waist) ...about how much bleeding is okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It should taper off tomorrow, but it can come back again. You have cramps? (Candy nods) They'll ease up, almost entirely. As long as the bleeding isn't heavy, it's normal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Catch!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (meaning the football) Give it here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What was *that*?! Come over here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer and Wally sit on the beach a short distance from Candy's blanket. She appears to be asleep. Wally looks in her direction before he speaks to Homer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally draws a crude map in the sand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On Candy's face: she's not asleep; she's listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer looks at Wally, thoughtfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer is shocked; he looks back at Candy, lowers his voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally nods; he also gives a look in Candy's direction before he responds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer's smile suggests that he's impressed, but that he wouldn't have Wally's enthusiasm for the task. Wally laughs and puts his hand on Homer's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's called the Burma run. It's about a seven-hour round-trip flight between India and China.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Burma run" because you fly over Burma...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: *And* over the Himalayas. That's called flying over the hump.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) At what altitude?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got thirty-five minutes to climb to fifteen thousand feet--that's the first mountain pass.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What lousy luck--I mean your orders... to draw an assignment like that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (conspiratorially) Actually, I volunteered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's the flying, right? You love to fly, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love the bombing, too. But there's also the Himalayas--they have the most wicked air currents in the world. I wouldn't miss flying there for anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh, look... if you're serious about wanting a job, picking apples isn't that boring.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I would love that, Wally.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The car is parked at a lobster pound. Homer sits in the car watching Wally carrying Candy's bag to the door. Candy stands outside the car; she shakes Homer's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy turns and heads toward the house to catch up with Wally. A lobsterman in his boat is approaching the dock. It's RAY, Candy's father. Candy waves. "Hi, Daddy!" Homer glances at Candy and Wally on the dock, kissing good-bye.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I guess I'll see you around the orchards. Thanks for everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure... I'll see you around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispering) I love you, Wally.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love you, too. See you tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Wally drives up to the Worthington house; he gets out of the car. Homer sits in the car, admiring the beautiful farmhouse.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come on. You have to meet my mom. (conspiratorially) If it comes up, I've been at a wedding. That's where I met you, at the wedding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer as never seen such a room: the sports trophies, the photos of athletic teams, and of Candy with Wally. Model airplanes are everywhere. Mrs. Worthington's voice comes from the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She appears in the doorway of Wally's room. Mrs. Worthington (OLIVE) is an elegant, fiftyish New Englander, as handsome as Wally, but more reserved. She is surprised to see Homer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally is taking his uniform off as he speaks, just dropping it on the floor as he quickly puts on some farm clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer has never met anyone like her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Worthington starts picking up her son's uniform from the floor. She is politely curious about Homer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer looks confused; he seems to have forgotten about the alleged wedding. Wally puts his arm around Homer, urging him into the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer is embarrassed, but Olive is obdurately well-mannered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally calls to her as he pushes Homer down the hall.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Wally? I expected you earlier...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is Homer Wells--he's the most overqualified apple picker you'll ever meet, but he's dying to learn the apple business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you do, Homer Wells...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you do...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Were you a friend of the bride or the groom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Homer is everybody's friend, Mom... the bride's, the groom's, mine, Candy's, *everybody's*.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, perhaps you'll come to dinner, Homer...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not tonight, Mom--he's got to meet *Mr. Rose*!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer and Wally get out of the jeep at the cider house, a barnlike building with adjacent sheds and, behind it, line after line of trees--the apple orchards. Homer sees an outdoor shower where THREE BLACK MEN are showering. It is a wooden stall that leaves the shower's occupants visible above and below their midsections.
