A FOURTH BLACK MAN is caught naked, running behind the cider house and out of sight as he wraps a towel around himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer wonders what that means as Wally reaches for the door of the cider house. Before Wally can knock, a pretty young black girl, ROSE ROSE, bumps open the screen door with her hip and throws a bucket of water in the grass--almost hitting Homer and Wally.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This gets the attention of the men on their way from the showers. They walk over, towels around their waists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The screen door swings open and shut again, startling them all, as MR. ROSE comes out of the cider house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grinning, Mr. Rose shakes Wally's hand. Rose Rose goes back inside the cider house as Mr. Rose shakes Homer's hand. Homer introduces himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Rose looks briefly at the men, who wait for his reaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally slaps Homer on the back; he goes inside the cider house to help Rose Rose with the plumbing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer looks at Mr. Rose for instructions. Mr. Rose stares back at him with his enigmatic smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer looks at Mr. Rose with an uncomprehending expression.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer thinks that over. Later, Homer is cleaning out the shed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You already used up the hot water!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're usin' my soap, ain't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I ain't usin' no soap--it's too cold to bother with soap!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There ain't never enough hot water, soap or no soap.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're migrants.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (no clue) Migrants?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. They pick fruit, all kinds. They travel up and down the coast with the seasons. (leaning close to Homer) The trick to Mr. Rose is, you have to let him be the boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That sink's backed up again, Wally. I thought you was gonna get me a plumber.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rose, this is Homer--Homer, this is Mr. Rose's daughter, Rose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rose Rose?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pretty, ain't it? You a plumber?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no--Homer is a new *picker*. He's going to stay here with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suspiciously) He's stayin' *here*?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE That daughter of mine sure is Miss Hospitality, ain't she, Wally?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE You got lots of experience pickin', I suppose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Homer's got no experience, Arthur, but he's smarter then I am. He's a fast learner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE This is history. Ain't that what you're sayin', Wally? I guess we makin' *history*... havin' this young man stay with us!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (over his shoulder) See you later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So. What should I do now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE Out back, there's a shed. It's just a mess. If that shed was better organized, I could put my truck in there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE If you're as smart as Wally says, you know you sometimes gotta do one job before you do another.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The pickers all sit down to supper around a picnic table. Homer with Mr. Rose, Rose Rose, and the other black pickers. Mr. Rose takes an apple from a bowl on the table. Then he pulls out a knife and opens it in one fluid motion; he's so fast, the knife seems to come out of nowhere. He begins to peel the apple. Homer eyes Mr. Rose, but Mr. Rose's focus is riveted to his apple and the long, perfect strand of peel dangling from it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peaches breaks the awkward silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer decides to stop. Another silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are some disrespectful suggestions from the pickers concerning what his heroism might have been.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Muddy scowls at Homer, but he smiles at Mr. Rose.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE You did a good job with that shed, Homer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What kind of a name is Homer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's the name of a cat. Originally. Well, not *originally*.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE Now, now--we all got names, sensible or not. (to Homer) Peaches is from Georgia, where we met him pickin' peaches. He's still better with peaches than hs is with apples. (Peaches grins) Jack here is new. And this here is Hero, 'cause he was a hero of some kind or other once. Ain't that right, Hero?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE And this here sensitive-lookin' fella is Muddy. The less said about Muddy, the better. Ain't that right, Muddy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer unpacks his suitcase. (His bed should be nearest Muddy's and Mr. Rose's.) Jack lies on his bed, smoking. Muddy, also smoking, is sitting on his bed, sharpening a knife. Hero and Peaches are playing cards on one of their beds. Mr. Rose is finishing shaving. Rose Rose watches Homer unpack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds up the X ray, in order to show her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rose Rose picks up the book that Homer has put on the bed. She studies the cover; it's "Great Expectations" by Charles Dickens. She puts it down, restlessly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody laughs, except Muddy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finished unpacking, Homer sits on his bed; he picks up "Great Expectations" and begins to read. Rose Rose sits down next to him, watching him read. Homer notices her interest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer smiles politely and goes back to his book. Rose Rose keeps looking over his shoulder at the pages.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer looks around at the pickers lying in their beds, smoking, listening. (Like bedtime stories at the orphanage, he thinks; however, the picker's attitude is suspicious, reserved.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer looks up; there's no response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some muttering, some giggling, mostly silence. Rose Rose wants more, but suddenly Jack jumps out of bed and stomps to the kitchen end of the cider house, where a piece of paper is tacked to the wall. Jack is talking to Homer all the way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack points at the piece of paper. Homer gets up and looks at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the men groan--Jack swears and Peaches laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the smokers laugh and cough in their beds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rose Rose stomps back to her bed. Her father absently snaps his towel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's just my heart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What you got a picture of your heart for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a little something wrong with it. Just this part here--the right ventricle. It's slightly enlarged.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, so what. It's nothing serious, really. Just a small defect.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE It's big enough to keep you out of the war, I suppose. Ain't that right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE They told me I was too old to serve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They told Muddy his feet was too flat!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Peaches) And you was "generally unfit," as I recall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you like to read?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (embarrassed) I can't read. Nobody taught me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing to the page) What does it say there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reading)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: looked at the stars, and considered how awful it would be for a man to turn his face to them as he froze to death, and see no help or pity in all the glittering multitude."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Rose Rose) More?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Since you're the one who's smart enough to read... what's this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a list of rules, it seems.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: *Whose* rules?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're for us, I suppose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go on and read 'em, Homer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "One. Please don't smoke in bed."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's too late for that one!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE (uncharacteristically blunt) Stop it, Homer. They aren't our rules. We didn't write them. I don't see no reason to read them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Everybody is asleep, except Homer. He is staring at the ceiling in the quiet semi-darkness, the book lying on his chest.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) (distant echoing) Good night, you Princes of Maine! You Kings of New England.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dr. Larch is standing in the doorway to the boys' room; he closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer, on his bed, closes his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch lies in bed with his eyes open. (No ether.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cider house and the apple orchard in the moonlight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally in his farm clothes at the wheel of the Jeep--he is racing through the orchards, dodging trees, with Homer in the passenger seat, hanging on for dear life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer is excited as Wally weaves among the trees--faster and faster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally brakes hard. The Jeep comes to a stop in the packing- house area. Candy has been waiting on the loading platform. The pickers are working in the background.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She pulls an apple branch, with an apple to two, out of the vehicle's grille--or else the branch is wedged in the front - bumper or headlight area. Candy playfully starts poking Wally with the branch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally gets the apple branch away from Candy. He pins her arms at her sides--he hugs her, kisses her. She doesn't struggle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all laugh. Homer observes the happy couple.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Remember this! In the morning, when the tall grass is wet, you can make the Jeep slide on the grass. Can you feel it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's almost like flying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about the trees?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The trees are flak--antiaircraft fire from those geeks on the ground.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (defensively to Candy) I was just showing Homer the orchards... kind of a geography lesson.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (good-naturedly) I know what you've been doing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Wally) You've been giving him a *flying* lesson!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (teasing her) He *loved* it! (to Homer) Didn't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, it was great.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing to Homer) He thinks people *like* to get whacked by branches.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: *Homer* liked it! (to Homer) Didn't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, sure. There's no stress or strain around here...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer is walking with Wally and Candy. The orchards are beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Much activity: the pickers are unloading apple crates from a full flatbed trailer. An angry-looking VERNON gives Homer an evil glare. Homer spills some apples lifting the crate to the loading platform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Rose takes Homer aside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally, in full uniform, appears from inside the packing house; he calls for Homer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer smiles are runs toward Wally.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE That's Vernon. You best stay away from him until he gets to know you better--then you best stay away from him *more*!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE Out lieutenant's calling you, Homer. Mind your ass.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer and Wally walk through the packing house, where the HEFTY, LOUD WOMEN sort through the apples rolling by on the conveyor tracks. Wally snatches an apple from one of them, giving it to Homer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before Homer can answer, the women interrupt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally makes an effort to introduce Homer, but he's interrupted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wally puts his hand to his heart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the women are left behind giggling, Wally continues talking to Homer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer shakes his head. Wally stops walking; they both stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer is unfamiliar with this kind of kidding around; at first he is startled, but then he laughs. Wally laughs, too. They shake hands. Mr. Rose calls out to Homer from the tractor. The pickers are impatiently waiting for him on the flatbed; they're going back to the orchard. Homer has to run to catch up to them. He jumps on the flatbed; he sees Wally waving good-bye.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Homer) You getting along okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is that Candy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did she leave you, Wally?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's the boy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wally, you can marry Debra if Candy leaves you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wally's gonna marry *me* if Candy leaves him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can marry all three of us, Wally!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We can take turns.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You girls make it hard for a guy to go off to war. (points to Homer) But I'll leave my best man here to pinch-hit for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh... I'm shipping out sooner than I thought. I just wanted to be sure you were settled in--and happy enough, considering... (grabbing another apple from a crate) Are you bored stiff? Or can you stick it out for a bit?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh... actually, picking apples is as much excitement as I want for a while. I'm grateful for the job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (his hand on Homer's shoulder) You're the one who's helping *me*, Homer. You're going to give my mom a little peace of mind while I'm gone. Candy, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, sure... that's good, then. (awkward pause) All I mean is, I'm lucky I met you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think so, Homer. *I'm* the lucky one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (more serious) You want to fight about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: High up in a tall tree on a couple of ladders, Mr. Rose and Homer are picking side by side. Mr. Rose is picking with high-speed perfection, but Homer is slower and fumbling--he drops an occasional apple to the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer nods; he picks more carefully, with more concentration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer can see over the apple mart parking lot from the top of the tree. He can see the driveway of the Worthington house, where Candy and Olive are saying a tearful good-bye to Wally. Distracted, Homer drops another couple of apples, which Mr. Rose observes with a wry smile.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE You pickin' more cider apples then anythin' else. Them drops is good only for cider. And you pickin' the stems with the apples only half the time. They good only for cider, too-- if you don't pick them stems. (Homer watches him) The rule is, you wanna pick the apple *with* the stem, Homer. And see here... see that *bud* that's just above the stem? That's the bud for *next year's* apple--that's called the *spur*. You pick the spur, you pickin' two years in one--you pickin' next year's apple 'fore it have a chance to grow. You leave that on the branch, you hear?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE (approvingly) That's better. I can tell you got yourself some education. Them's good hands you got, Homer. Them hands you got, they know what they're doin'-- ain't that right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess so...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Wilbur! Wilbur!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Larch is doing something at his desk when Angela comes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch stares at Angela, who holds a letter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wilbur, you should read this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's from the Board. Another letter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dr. Larch stands in front of a mechanical drawing easel. He works intently with a calligraphic pen, but we don't see what he's working on. Angela and Edna sit at the desk; they're looking over the letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch puts down the pen, comes around the easel, opens a drawer in a filing cabinet, and hands Edna a folder containing a few cleanly typed pages. Larch returns to the easel, to his painstaking work. Edna opens the file; as she and Angela read the contents, Larch recites from memory as he works.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edna and Angela think this over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch turns the easel around. Attached is a parchment headed: "HARVARD MEDICAL SCHOOL"--it's a diploma-in-progress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The women are shocked, awed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (quoting the letter) Uh... "merely suggesting that some new blood might benefit you all... someone with new ideas in the obstetrical and pediatric fields." (she looks up at Larch) I think they're just testing some ideas for our next meeting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Holtz seems nice. I think he only wants to help...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He is a goddamn psychiatrist--of *course* he wants to "help"! He'd be happy if he could help *commit* me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's that Mrs. Goodhall you have to be careful of, Wilbur.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One has to be more than "careful" of Mrs. Goodhall--she has sufficient Christian zeal to start her own country! I'd like to give her a little ether.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So what are you going to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Homer Wells, born Portland, Maine, March 2, 1915..."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Homer was born *here*, in, what was it, 1922?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...graduated Bowdoin College, 1935, and Harvard School of Medicine, 1939."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is *your* life story, Wilbur! You just changed the dates!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "An internship and two years of training at the Boston Lying-in, South End Branch. For his age, he was judged an accomplished gynecological obstetrical surgeon; he is also experienced in pediatric care..."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You *invented* him! You've completely made his up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you understand? The board is going to *replace* me! That's what the "new blood" is *for*!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean they'll replace you with someone who won't perform abortions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sarcastically) Well, we can only guess about that, Edna. They *are* against the law.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These *credentials* are against the law!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We all know who trained Homer--his credentials are as good as mine are. Don't you be holy to me about the *law*! What has the law done for any of us here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (points at file) So here is my candidate. What do you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But what about school records? Homer doesn't have any *diplomas*...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He *will* have them, Edna.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Wilbur, I don't know... (sudden thought) We don't even know where he is!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Where's that Homer? Homer stands in front of a ladder that leans against the cider house; he starts to climb up, drawn by the murmuring voices, the soft laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer arrives at the top and sees everyone sitting on a long plank, a bench attached to the apex of the roof--obviously a popular spot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one moves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peaches slides over and Homer sits down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The others laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More laughter; Homer smiles, enjoying the teasing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rose Rose is being physically affectionate with her father-- lightly punching his arm, rubbing the top of his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all look up, imagining that. Homer more than the others. Rose Rose, looking thoughtful, rests her head on her father's shoulder. They are completely natural together.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Who cares?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE (O.S.) Now, now. He's a good boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Shit. We don't know what he is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE (O.S.) Jack, you gotta watch your language 'round my daughter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE Here he is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE Where's your manners? Make room for Homer, so's he can enjoy the view.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What view?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are we supposed to be up here? The rules said...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE Homer, you the only one who's read them rules, so you the only one who feels like he's doin' somethin' wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: *What* view?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE Well, Muddy, we can look at all these angry stars Homer's been readin' to us about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gesturing toward the Worthington farmhouse) I bet the view looks better from the Worthin'tons'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE You think so, Jack? Well... I wouldn't want to be in that Wally's shoes tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (playfully, teasing him) Daddy, I'd like to be in that Wally's shoes *every* night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE (teasing her back) You lucky you in your work boots tonight, girl...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's lucky about that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE You know where that Wally is tonight, darlin'? He's up there in them angry stars. (gesturing at the dark sky) He's flyin' all around up there... with them Japs shooting at him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer and the pickers are loading crates of apples into a shipping truck. Olive and Candy are consulting some papers (the shipping tally) on a clipboard; Mr. Rose is standing beside them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She catches Homer's eye; he smiles, then joins them. Mr. Rose puts his arm around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Olive is looking over the rest of the picking crew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He means Jack, who gives Olive and Candy and Mr. Rose a furtive look. Olive smiles at Rose Rose, who comes up to her and Candy. Olive touches Rose Rose with affection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy takes Rose Rose by the shoulders and turns her around. Rose Rose is enjoying this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts leading his daughter away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Olive waves good-bye as she moves toward her car. Candy turns to Homer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer has the hardest time looking at Candy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer shakes his head. He looks at the tractor and the empty trailer. Mr. Rose and the pickers are just watching them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer looks toward the pickers sitting on the flatbed when he hears the tractor start. Candy follows his gaze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Rose gestures for Muddy to drive off; the tractor trailer pulls away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer has to run to catch up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He jumps on the back of the departing flatbed between Mr. Rose and Rose Rose, as Candy watches him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE They all on board, Mrs. Worthin'ton.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Arthur. (see is looking at Homer) And how is our Homer working out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE Oh, he's a smart young man, most of the time--Wally was right about him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No rotten apples?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE (it's an old way of speaking that they have) No, no--not this year. Well... maybe we got *one*, but it ain't Homer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rose... dear girl, I'm sure I can find you some other clothes. (to Candy) You must have some things that would fit her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have a *ton* of things that would fit you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE Now, now, Candy--this girl don't need no more clothes, not for pickin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (charming) Arthur, there's no such thing as a young woman who's got all the clothes she needs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So. Not bored yet?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm *never* bored! It's all very... different for me... here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh... have you been *feeling* okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I'm not thinking about Wally. I'm not good at being alone. (realizing) Oh, goodness. You meant... yes, I'm fine. I... (struggling to change the subject) ...I don't suppose you've seen a lobster yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (more seriously) You have to come to my dad's lobster pound and see one, then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I better go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think Mr. Rose would leave without you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) Sorry!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling) Come next week!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: An anxious-looking WHITE PLUMBER is fixing the kitchen sink while the pickers (in their towels) stand around and watch. Homer is putting on his best shirt. Peaches admires the shirt as Rose Rose cooks the night's supper on the wood stove.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The pickers all look at Homer, who looks guilty as he leaves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Whoa--look at that Homer! He's gettin' all dressed up for supper tonight!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He ain't gettin' dressed to have supper with *us*, Peaches!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE (to the plumber) Don't let us make you nervous or nothin'--we know you gotta job to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, we can wait all night for the water to come back on--you just go on and take your time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer pedals a bicycle down a dirt road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray holds a lobster up to the camera. We see the old-fashioned wooden pens, floating dockside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer looks uncertain.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hungry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer and Ray and Candy go up the gangplank from the dock to the lobster pound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Later, through the window of the lobster pound, we see them eating lobster around a kitchen table. Laughter and some unclear dialogue drift to us.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They're the garbage-eaters of the ocean's floor. The seagulls clean up the shore. The lobsters clean up the bottom of the sea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They eat everything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everything that falls to the bottom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's time somebody ate *them*.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Candy) I was lookin' for Wally's letter. I was gonna show it to Homer... (to Homer) They made him a captain already-- *Captain* Worthington!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Daddy, it's a letter to *me*.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He mentions Homer, too, you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (awkwardly) Wally said to say, "Hello."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (equally awkward) Oh! That's... nice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Homer) Wally said the most spectacular hits were in the oil fields at Yenangyat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: With the bicycle stowed in the trunk, Candy is driving Homer back to the cider house. They pass a drive-in movie theatre, the marquee announcing "CLOSED FOR THE SEASON." Homer stares in awe at the giant blank screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy looks at him; he isn't joking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer laughs a little self-consciously; around her, he feels like he's *still* a kid.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A movie *outside*?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. But it's closed all the time now, because of the blackout.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: People watched the movies in their cars?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) When they watched at all. Do you like movies?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes! I've only seen one, though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've seen only one movie? Which one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "King Kong". It's really good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't seen "King Kong" since I was a kid!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: At one table, the children are happily eating apples; a few of the kids are stuffing apples from a big bowl into their pockets. At another table, Larch, Edna, and Angela sit around an open packing crate of apples. Larch takes a bite from an apple and spits it out. Angela takes the apple out of his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Angela hands him another apple.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Angela gives him a critical look as Larch takes a bite out of the new apple.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Both Edna and Angela glower at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch angrily tosses the half-eaten apple into the garbage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch stares into space, depressed. Then he examines the crate and finds the mailing label that says "OCEAN VIEW ORCHARDS--CAPE KENNETH, MAINE." He rips it off, holds it up triumphantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch storms out of the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's a pie apple, Wilbur. Homer said you're not supposed to eat it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So he's an apple expert, is he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sarcastically) Oh my, yes! This is a *far* superior taste--and crisp, too! You know, so many apples are disappointingly mealy. I wonder of most of the apples in my life weren't meant for pies!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wilbur, he picked them for us himself...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (incredulous) You don't find it depressing that Homer Wells is picking apples?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or that he can't be bothered to write us a proper letter? A dissertation on apples, we don't need!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (annoyed) He probably doesn't make much money picking apples--he must have had to pay to send them, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wouldn't worry, Edna, that he doesn't have money. If he gets hungry, he can pick his dinner!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wilbur, it's a *gift*! How can you be angry with Homer for sending us a *gift*?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll show him a *gift*! I'll give him a gift he can *use*!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A newsreel from the war is playing on the screen--soldiers marching, smiling, waving to the camera. Homer and Candy sit together watching. Homer is completely fascinated; Candy watches Homer as much as the news. Her expression changes when the newsreel cuts to footage from an air raid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy and Homer walk out of the theatre, under the marquee and past the poster for "Wuthering Heights."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy makes a face, but in good fun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer is embarrassed; he ducks the question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer smiles and shakes his head; Candy starts to laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer smiles; he knows she's teasing him, and he likes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy pushes him playfully. They're both having a good time, *too* good a time.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (disappointed) But you looked as if you liked it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) I *did* like it. All I said was, "It's not 'King Kong'."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: First she loved him, then she didn't, then no one else could have him...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She *did* love him! (teasing him) How many women have you known?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what did she die of, exactly?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She was torn apart! She died of a broken heart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, sure!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the *medical* explanation?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, she was in a weakened condition... (laughs) I don't know! What about "King Kong"?! Is that medically possible?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mock serious) At least King Kong knew what he *wanted*.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer is picking apples in a big tree; Rose Rose is on a ladder in the tree right beside him. She's picking about twice as fast as he is, and he keeps dropping his apples. In another tree, Muddy is watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From the surrounding trees, the other pickers laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In adjacent trees, both Peaches and Hero are picking apples; they can hear Homer and Rose Rose, too. (So can Mr. Rose.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The men *oooh* and *aaah* at Homer's announcement--Mr. Rose, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camera closes on Homer's face; he keeps picking.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is you *doin'* with that Candy, Homer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (imitating Mr. Rose) He's makin' history, I suppose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ain't gettin' in no trouble, I hope.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That Candy--she's the nicest girl I know!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's about the most beautiful girl I ever seen--I don't know if she's the nicest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's the nicest *and* the most beautiful girl I've ever known.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That sounds like you is in trouble already, Homer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE That's right--that sounds like trouble to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not in trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, you is. I know when people is in trouble, and you is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) His name is Homer Wells...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOUD'S - DINING HALL - EVENING Edna and Angela face the Board of Trustees around a table. Larch circles the table as everyone reads the contents of a folder. Larch has provided a copy for each member. The three elderly gentlemen on the Board don't speak; they just nod their heads to everything Dr. Holtz or Mrs. Goodhall says.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly Steerforth bursts through the door, having been pushed from behind by Mary Agnes. The two stop when they see what's going on--not to mention Larch's stern expression. They back out. Mary Agnes winking at Dr. Holtz before the door closes. Mrs. Goodhall is ready to continue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The three elderly gentlemen repeat the name.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...and his *pathetic* resume is the best I've seen. Though I find it hard to believe the Board would be interested in this character.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HOLTZ But he looks like an excellent young man, a first-rate candidate!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He looks like a bleeding-heart missionary *moron* to me, but that's going to be the problem with any doctor interested in coming here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GOODHALL Do you know him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: *No*! I don't want to know him! He's doing *missionary* work--in *India*! I wrote him *weeks* ago, but he's either too holy or too busy to answer. Maybe he got killed in the war!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GOODHALL I fail to see how someone courageous enough to make a commitment to a foreign mission is automatically to be dismissed--that part of the world requires precisely the kind of dedication that is needed here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does it *snow* in Bombay? One winter here and we'll be shipping him south, in a *coffin*!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GOODHALL You can't think that a man who has *served* under such conditions as exist over there will be in the slightest daunted by a little *snow*-- have you no idea how harsh and primitive and full of *disease* that part of the world is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then I suppose we can look forward to catching various diseases from him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HOLTZ But, Dr. Larch, he seems exceptionally qualified...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not talking about his medical qualifications. It's the *Christian* thing that bothers me--I just don't see it being of much *use* around here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GOODHALL (bitterly) I fail to see how a little Christianity could *hurt* anyone here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anyway, I was just showing you this guy as an example of what's available-- I didn't think you'd be interested.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HOLTZ We're *very* interested!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GOODHALL Yes, *very*!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HOLTZ You wouldn't be opposed to meeting with him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I suppose it wouldn't hurt to *meet* him. What's his name again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Homer Wells.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mumbling) I just hope he won't expect us to say *Grace* all the time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GOODHALL It's a nice name, very New England.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HOLTZ Very *Maine*, a very *local*-sounding name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: *Very*!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A song plays on the old phonograph as a happy Larch and Angela dance. Edna interrupts them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This causes Larch to take the needle off the record.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I just wanted to ask you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Edna! Come dance with me! Let's be foolish tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does he *know* he's supposed to be in India? Does he even *want* to come back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) He's a field hand! What could possibly hold him there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The rain beats down on Olive's car. Homer gets soaking wet as he leans in to talk to Candy, who's behind the wheel. Mr. Rose calls to Homer from the doorway of the mill room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Rose is instructing Homer as they stand bottling cider in their yellow slickers and rubber boots. Rose Rose is hosing down the pressboards; Muddy and Hero and Peaches are operating the grinder and the press. Jack is stirring the vat. In a defiant, contemptuous way, Jack keeps flicking the ash of his cigarette into the vat. This make everyone uncomfortable; only Mr. Rose doesn't appear to notice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone but Jack laughs. He takes a last drag on his cigarette, then deliberately drops it into the vat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack looks for a translation from the other men, who are nervous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack pulls a knife on Mr. Rose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We never see Mr. Rose's knife. We see the men circle each other: Jack takes a swipe at Mr. Rose's head--then he steps back, his yellow slicker slashed open. His slicker is opened up, right up the middle. His shirt underneath the slicker is slashed open, too--he feels his bare chest and stomach, feeling for the cut. But there's no cut--Jack's not bleeding, he's not even scratched. Just his clothes have been slashed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Muddy turns Jack around and views his slashed clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack starts to undress for the vat. Mr. Rose ushers Homer and Rose Rose outside.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE Cider don't have no taste till later in October--it's too watery now, when we're usin' just them early Macs and them Gravensteins. You don't get no *good* cider till you're pickin' them Golden Delicious and them Winter Bananas, them Baldwins and them Russerts...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about the worms? Most of these apples are the drops--off the ground, right? There have to be worms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE Of *course* there's worms, Homer! And what is them worms, really? They just *protein*, them worms! They is *good* for you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE That just ain't right, Jack--your cigarette's gonna end up in nine or ten gallons of this batch of cider! That ain't right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Them people drinkin' that cider, they don't know there's a cigarette in there!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE It's not that hard to find it in there, Jack--it'll take you just a minute. You just gotta go fishin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean *swimmin'*. I ain't goin' in that vat to fish out no cigarette!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE What business is you in, Jack? Just tell me what your business is...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just say you're in the *apple* business, man. That's the only business you wanna be in. Just say it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispers excitedly to Jack) You don't wanna go in the knife business with Mistuh Rose--just say you're in the *apple* business, Jack!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Mr. Rose) What business are *you* in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE I'm in the *knife* business, Jack. You don't wanna go in the knife business with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're lucky he didn't cut your *nipples* off, man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The good news, Jack, is you're half- undressed for *swimmin'*...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, that cigarette ain't hard to find when you're properly undressed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mr. Rose has cut his own hand in the fight. Homer's professionalism if offended to watch Rose Rose's amateurish efforts to stitch up her father's wound, but clearly this isn't the first time she's done it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer can't bear to watch Rose Rose at work with the needle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer winces at the stitching.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Give men that. I know how to do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I suppose you is a doctor, Homer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Almost.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE I don't need no "almost" a doctor, Homer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We should drown that damn Jack in the vat!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE Now, now, darlin'... Jack just needs to know what business he's in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, you really showed him, Daddy-- you just about cut your own hand off, and all you cut off *him* was his clothes!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE You oughta know you don't go to jail for cuttin' a guy's *clothes*. Ain't that right, Homer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Wally's car comes bouncing along the ditches of the closed drive-in. Homer is at the wheel; Candy calls out some driving instructions. The car comes to a stop next to a speakerpost. Candy leans out; she grabs the speaker and hangs it on the window. Homer sits back and drapes his arms out the window and over the seat. He feels great.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer looks up at the giant movie screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer stares at Candy in disbelief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy looks at him for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy is moved. Homer feels exposed; he tries to change the mood by making light of what he's said.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the mention of Wally they both look a little self- conscious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy looks at Homer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy scrunches down in her seat; Homer imitates her. Homer is focused on the giant screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer's expression changes from exhilarated to guilty. He leans back in his seat and looks straight ahead at the screen. Candy tentatively leans her head on his shoulder. Homer looks afraid to breathe. From behind, with her head on his shoulder, they look like a normal couple. We track in toward the huge screen until we see only the screen. There are shadows on the black screen. Suddenly the movie "King Kong" appears.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're a natural. You were born to drive a car like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think? Maybe I was. (looks around) I love this place!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The screen is enormous! Imagine King Kong up *there*! Have you seen a lot of movies here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes... and no. When you come here, you don't really care about the movie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't care about the movie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you so crazy about the movies for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was my favorite night at the orphanage--movie night. We'd race into the dining hall. Of course everyone wanted to sit in front, so we'd be packed in so tight you could feel the kid next to you breathing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At least you were never lonely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't say that. Growing up in an orphanage, you're always lonely. You're just never alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not alone in the bathroom, or... or in the shower... you're never alone in wanting the last piece of meatloaaf, or even in your own bed on a cold morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't miss it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I miss things. I miss... people. (with certainty) I miss reading to the boys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you had so much *responsibility*.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never *asked* for any responsibility.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just a little privacy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Privacy is exactly the point of drive- in movies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you come here with Wally--to *not* watch movies?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sometimes... movies mostly bore Wally.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah-ha. (points to the speaker) So what is that--a radio?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The *speaker*. For the movie sound.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Scrunch down like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How could you not *care* about the movie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You just cuddle. You come to hug... to kiss. You don't *come* here to watch the movie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (teasing her) That's what *I'd* come here for. I'd watch the movie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not with the right girl you wouldn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ing Kong" is playing against the bare, white wall. Fuzzy is very weak, but he smiles at the sight of the love-struck Kong holding the screaming Fay Wray in his giant hand. Dr. Larch runs the projector; he sits close beside Fuzzy. When the film breaks in the predictable place, Fuzzy makes no protest. Dr. Larch looks at Fuzzy, who has stopped breathing; his eyes are closed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are alone in the dining hall. Larch has wheeled in Fuzzy for a private viewing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Fuzzy? Fuzzy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOUD'S - GRAVEYARD - MORNING Buster helps Larch lower the small coffin into the grave. The tiny gravestone says "F.S."
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What are you going to tell the little ones?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll tell them Fuzzy was adopted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why would the little ones believe that *anyone* would adopt him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They'll believe it because they want to believe it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shouldn't we tell Homer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If Homer wanted to know what was happening here, he could pick up a telephone and call us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The boys in their beds listen to Buster inventing Fuzzy's "family."
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It was a family with a better breathing machine then the one Dr. Larch built.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOUD'S - CORRIDOR - NIGHT Larch leans against the wall, covering his eyes, overhearing the boys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch pauses; he waits to see if they believe this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch almost breaks with a sudden sharp breath.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) The family that adopted Fuzzy, they *invented* the breathing machine. It's their business... breathing machines.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Lucky Fuzzy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Good night, Fuzzy! Good night, Fuzzy! Good night, Fuzzy Stone!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As the men sit at the picnic table eating their cornbread, Rose Rose pours coffee. A jeep comes down the orchard road toward them. It's Olive. Mr. Rose leads the "Good mornin', Mrs. Worthin'ton!" greeting. Olive has an armful of clothing and a fairly sizable package; she brings the latter over to Homer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer shakes the package; he puts the package beside the table, unopened. Olive turns to Rose Rose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Rose watches Rose Rose and Olive disappear into the cider house. The other men view Homer's package with curiosity, especially Peaches.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Some mail for you, Homer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And some clothes for you, dear-- (nodding to the cider house) let's go see if they fit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ain't you gonna see what it is, Homer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE Mind your own business, Peaches.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, Homer...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer lies awake in bed; everyone else is asleep. Homer pulls the package out from under his bed, opening it just enough to see what it is; then he shoves it back under his bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The beach at sunset. Candy and Homer, dressed for cooler weather, are alone at the water's edge. From a paper bag, Candy is scattering some small, brightly colored pieces of broken glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She finds and old piece of glass among the stones and shells at the high-tide mark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy holds up a piece of glass to the sun for Homer to look at. The ocean is a gray-green color, the glass a paler shade of green.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She rubs the smooth piece of glass against his hand, then throws it toward the water. It falls short. Homer retrieves it. Candy splashes him playfully. He chases her away from the beach, into the pine trees. Homer locks his arms around her, from behind. He can't let go. She lets him hold her, then breaks his grip. She turns to face him. She is taller then he is, older, obviously more experienced. She initiates the kiss. They drop to the ground right there; they make love by the roots of the tree, Candy guiding him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Aren't you worried that people will cut their feet?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody will swim here until next summer. By then, the water will have rubbed the glass smooth against the sand--there won't be any sharp edges.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See? That's last year's glass, or from some year before. I put glass here every year. The ocean makes it beautiful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give me your hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They come out of the woods, walking toward the car, Candy leading. We hear Candy talking just before we see her and Homer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sits in the passenger seat, Homer in the driver's seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer concentrates on starting the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their expressions, as the car pulls away, belie their words.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (increasingly upset) *Nobody* volunteers for the Burma run--he said so himself. And nobody knows *me* better than him! So how am I supposed to feel? He's a bomber pilot and I'm just selfish, I know. Well, I'm *not* a brave little girl and I'm *not* sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: *know* this was right. (pause) I told you. I'm not good at being alone. (pause; in a whisper) I told him, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (repeating herself) I *know* this was right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer and Mr. Rose sit opposite each other at the picnic table. Rose Rose stands behind her father, her hands on his shoulders, watching Homer snip out Mr. Rose's stitches--very quickly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Job done, Homer leaves the table and hurries to the bicycle, pedaling away. Rose Rose watches Homer go, as Mr. Rose flexes his healed hand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE Slow down, Homer--don't be in such a big hurry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is easy--I'm not hurrying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE You still doin' it too fast!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's in a big hurry, all right. I told you he's in trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Candy and Homer sit on the dock. Candy still seems to be wrestling with her conscience. Homer throws snails in the sea. It's cold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer throws a snail with more force.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray comes out onto the dock; he sees Homer throwing another snail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy throws a handful of snails into the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray looks at the two of them; he sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray nods good night; he leaves. Homer looks expectantly at Candy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Just tell me. Do you want me to go? Do you want me to stay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It will be okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: *What* will be okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have to wait and see. I think that, for *everything* in life, you have to wait and see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll just move on, get another job somewhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every time you throw a snail off the dock, you're makin' someone start his whole life over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe we're doing the snails a favor, Daddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's gettin' late. I think I'll pack it in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good night, Daddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll just have to wait and see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Olive and Homer sit at the dining-room table, the remnants of an apple pie in front of them. Homer is still eating. Pictures of Wally are on the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer nods in sympathy. His mouth is stuffed with apple pie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Olive's thoughts drift; her eyes look up at a photo of Wally.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer is tense. Does Olive suspect about Candy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both laugh, but Homer has a hard time looking her in the eye.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I used to hate it when Wally went back to college--even when it was just college! And this was when his father was still alive... I hated it even then. Naturally I hate this more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What I mean is... I would like it very much if you thought you could be happy here, Homer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wiping his mouth) Mrs. Worthington, I feel I'm very lucky to be here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's not a lot of work in the winter, and you'll have to tolerate Vernon--even Wally despises him, and Wally likes everyone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think Wally will be fine, Mrs. Worthington--he seems indestructible to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (distracted) I don't know. (intently at Homer) Just promise me one thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh... sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just promise me that, if there's a blizzard, you'll move into Wally's room until it's over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The pickers are moving out; the harvest is over. Olive and Homer stand near the door to the bunkhouse, talking--we can't hear their conversation. Rose Rose and the other men walk past them, carrying the last of their belongings to the truck. Olive and Homer walk over to the truck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They shake hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Olive gets in her Jeep and waves as she drives off. The truck is packed. Muddy tugs on a rope that secures the load.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Rose nods and gets in behind the wheel. Rose Rose and Muddy get in next to him. The others are bundled up for the ride in the open back of the truck. As they're leaving, Homer waves good-bye--the pickers calling out to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer stands looking after them, after they're gone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good-bye. Have a safe trip home. Thank you, again, for all your hard work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE You take care now, Mrs. Worthin'ton.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good-bye, Arthur. (she hugs Rose Rose) Homer, I'll see you tomorrow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Mr. Rose) We all set, I think.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE You all take care of yourself, too, Homer!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We see you next harvest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't freeze to death, Homer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go on and freeze to death if you want to, Homer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE Now, now, Jack--that just ain't right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You just stay out of trouble, Homer!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer is alone, rearranging his stuff--spreading out a bit, making the place his own. (On the other beds, we see the mattresses rolled up on the bare bedsprings.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer turns; he hadn't seen Candy come in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles. He goes to her; they embrace.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) So, you're staying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Olive told me. (awkward pause) You might have told me yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm just waiting and seeing. Like you said.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.ToD: THE NEXT NINE OR TEN MONTHS

direction.raw_text: Homer, drinking coffee, is writing a letter on a note pad.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Dear Dr. Larch, thank you for your doctor's bag...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer is learning how to "haul" a lobster pot with Ray and Candy's guidance.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...although it seems that I will not have the occasion to use it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Following Ray's example, Homer is trying to "disarm" the lobsters' big claws by blocking them shut with the little wooden wedges. Roy works quickly, never getting pinched. As Candy watches, Homer gets pinched.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Barring some emergency, of course. I am not a doctor. With all due respect to your profession. I am enjoying my life here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer and Candy are naked. They have pulled two beds together and made a double bed. He can't take his eyes off her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I've looked at so many women... I mean, I've seen *everything* about them, *everything*... but I never felt a thing. I felt nothing. Now... with you... it *hurts*... to look at you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edna and Angela and Larch are all reading Homer's letter, their lips moving silently as they read the words.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I am enjoying being a lobsterman and an orchardman--in fact, I have never enjoyed myself so much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Olive and Homer and Candy are playing a board game around the fireplace.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) The truth is, I want to stay here. I believe I am being of *some* use.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edna and Angela view him anxiously from the doorway as Larch furiously types and types.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) My dear Homer, I thought you were over your adolescence, that period which I would define as the first time in our lives when we imagine we have something terrible to hide from those who love us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Candy is singing to the car radio, as animated and happy as we've ever seen her. Homer, driving, can scarcely keep his eyes on the road; he has to keep looking at her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Do you think it's not obvious to us what's happened to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: With the radio playing (a popular song), Homer hops across the bare floor, pulling on his boxer shorts; he opens the door to Olive, who's holding out an armload of blankets to him. He sheepishly thanks her. When Homer closes the door, we see a hidden (and stricken) Candy, naked from their interrupted lovemaking.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) You're fallen in love, haven't you? By the way, whatever you're up to can't be too good for your heart. Then again, it's the sort of condition that can be made worse by worrying about it. So don't worry about it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Vernon and Homer are working under an apple tree; they are poisoning mice.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Dear Dr. Larch, what I am learning here may not be as important as what I learned from you, but everything is new to me. Yesterday I learned how to poison mice. You use poison oats and poison corn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Supper chaos--Buster and Mary Agnes are doing their best to stop a food fight while Larch and Angela and Edna are completely absorbed reading Homer's letter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Field mice girdle an apple tree. Pine mice kill the roots. I *know* what you have to do--you have to play God. Well... killing mice is as close as I want to come to playing God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer and Candy are watching "Rebecca".
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Do I interfere? When absolutely helpless women tell me that they simply *can't* have an abortion, that they simply *must* go through with having another--and yet another-- orphan... do I interfere? *Do* I? I do not. I do not even *recommend*. I just give them what they want: an orphan or an abortion. (close on Homer) You are my work of art, Homer. Everything else has been just a job. I don't know if you've got a work of art in you, but I know what your job is. You're a doctor!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The radio is playing a slow, sexy dance number. The fat ladies from the apple mart are dancing as they paint the interior walls of the bunk house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer is finishing up painting the kitchen walls. When he gets to the list of rules, tacked on the wall, he removes the list and finishes painting under where the rules were.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two of the ladies unroll the rolled-up mattresses on the bare bedsprings, as Vernon enters with an armload of blankets and pillows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer holds up the list of rules, rereads it briefly; he walks over to an unpainted beam, a support beam, and tacks the rules on this beam.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I am not a doctor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) You know everything I know, plus what you've taught yourself--you're a better doctor then I am and you know it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) They're going to replace me, Homer! The Board of Trustees is looking for my *replacement*!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I can't replace you! I'm sorry...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer reads Larch's letter, sipping coffee.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Sorry? I'm not 'sorry'! Not for anything I've done. I'm not even sorry that I love you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Larch sits on his ether-bed with a letter from Homer in his hand. He looks completely deflated. Angela is standing in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I think we may have lot him to the world. He's not coming back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In the newly painted, spruced-up cider house, Homer and Candy are dancing to another slow, sexy song on the radio. He is untucking her blouse, feeling under her blouse--she starts to unbutton his shirt. They kiss while they dance. But the song changes abruptly on the radio to something fast and silly. Homer responds to the music, dancing goofily--instantly out of the mood. Candy laughs, but she picks up a pillow and swings it at him, hitting him. He dances away from her. She throws the pillow; he ducks--the pillow lands somewhere near the door. Now Homer grabs a pillow and chases her from bed to bed. She shrieks--they're both laughing. They each grab a pillow and stand toe to toe whacking each other, laughing all the while, until he pins her arms behind her and, breathing hard--and despite the stupid music that broke the mood--they are passionately kissing again. The sound of a truck is sudden and loud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Rose's truck has arrived. The pickers are hopping out of the truck, grabbing their gear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door opens. Hero and Peaches barge in, as Homer and Candy are struggling to return the pillows to the beds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Muddy is right behind them. He picks up a pillow, off the floor, looking for which bed it belongs on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then comes Mr. Rose, slyly smiling, taking it all in--there's no hiding what's going on. Homer and Candy are caught, their shirts untucked and half-unbuttoned--they're still out of breath. The pillows lie crazily on the beds, each one of which has been stepped on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rose Rose enters. She looks hardened, toughened--not happy. She plops down her stuff on her bed, looking only at Candy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer tries to help out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He peters out, knowing how sick of hearing this Candy is. He tries to change the subject.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is an uncomfortable silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One look at Muddy and we know something pretty bad happened to Jack.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's that Homer!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's that Candy, too...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE Don't this place look like home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It look nicer then home!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE What have you two been doin' to make it look so nice?

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, he's fine! I just heard from him. He's bombing all these places...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mumbling) ...bridges, oil refineries, fuel depots...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where's Jack?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He just wasn't up for the trip.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE That Jack just never knew what his business was.

direction.raw_text: The pickers on their ladders, all picking. Homer is now a good picker; he looks over at Rose Rose. She is slumped against the ladder, not picking, completely ignoring an argument beneath them in the aisle between the trees. (Mr. Rose is checking over the apples Peaches has just picked.)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE You pickin' nothin' but cider apples, Peaches--I hope you understand that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They ain't drops--I picked 'em off the tree!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE Then you pickin' 'em too fast--they ain't no better than drops to me. See that bruise, and that one? *Half* of these is bruised! Look at this one! It ain't got no stem! You might as well *step* on 'em, too--they only good for cider.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In the aisle between the trees, Homer and Candy are arguing in one of the work vehicles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her sudden hardness leaves him speechless as they go their separate ways. Candy drives on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think I'm having a good time? Do you think I'm just *teasing* you? Do you think I *know* whether I want you or Wally?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So we should "wait and see." For how long?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I grew up with Wally. I began my adult life with him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine. That's all there is to it then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! That's not all there is to it! I love you, too--I *know* I do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, okay--I know you do, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bitterly) It's a good thing I didn't have that baby, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Breakfast time at the picnic table. Rose Rose by herself, away from the table. She does not look well; she suddenly goes back inside the bunkhouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer gets up to take his dishes inside.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (calling after her) Ain't you eatin' with us, Rose? (to the men) She used to eat with us. Now we ain't good enough for her, I guess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She ain't hungry, maybe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She ain't hungry every mornin' 'cause she's sick every mornin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: When Homer comes in, Rose Rose is throwing up in the sink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rose Rose lies down on her bed with the curtain open. There is something familiar about the way Homer approaches her bedside; he does so with the authority of a doctor. He sits on the edge of her bed with such complete self-assurance that she doesn't protest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She just stares. But she doesn't stop him when he touches her abdomen. It's as if she knows that he knows what he's doing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is taken back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She rolls over on the bed, facing away from him again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You okay, Rose?

dialogue.raw_text: I guess you must like watchin' me be sick...

dialogue.raw_text: I don't like watching anyone be sick.

dialogue.raw_text: You're not yet three months, are you?

dialogue.raw_text: Not yet. What do you know about it?

dialogue.raw_text: But you don't look very happy.

dialogue.raw_text: *Happy*! What are you thinkin'? How am I supposed to take care of a baby! I can't have a baby.

dialogue.raw_text: What I mean is, if you don't want to... keep the baby, I know a place where you can go.

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you just go back to your pickin', Homer? I can take care of it myself!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rose, listen--don't *do* anything. You know, I mean to yourself. Please listen...

dialogue.raw_text: . ROSE (O.S.) (calling) Homer! Is this a workin' day or what?

direction.raw_text: Homer and Candy are sitting at the dock.

direction.raw_text: Homer doesn't respond.

direction.raw_text: Homer looks out over the ocean; he remains unresponsive.

dialogue.raw_text: We should take her to St. Cloud's. That much is obvious, isn't it? Let her make up her mind when she gets there...

dialogue.raw_text: We have to do *something*. Don't we? (beat) Homer?
