direction.raw_text: Rose Rose is setting the picnic table for lunch when Candy arrives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She keeps setting the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rose Rose looks down.

direction.raw_text: Rose Rose dismissively waves her hand.

direction.raw_text: Rose Rose shakes her head again, more emphatically.

direction.raw_text: Rose Rose stays silent.

direction.raw_text: Rose Rose stops; she can't even continue setting the table. Her voice turns bitter, despairing.

direction.raw_text: There, suddenly, is Mr. Rose, walking past them. He is uncharacteristically tentative.

direction.raw_text: Mr. Rose leaves Candy and Rose Rose alone again. Rose Rose nods almost invisibly after her father. Rose Rose looks pointedly at Candy, nodding. Candy slowly gets it. Mr. Rose is the father! Rose Rose lets that sink in; she keeps looking at Candy with an ashamed expression.

dialogue.raw_text: Hi...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi...

dialogue.raw_text: I don't need no more clothes, thank you.

Homer is high on a ladder; he turns toward the view of the Worthington house when he hears a car come to a screeching halt in the driveway. Homer sees Candy get out of Wally's car; she leaves the door open and runs toward the house. Parked in front of Wally's car is an Army Jeep, with an ENLISTED MAN leaning against it. The indifferent soldier smokes a cigarette as he watches Candy run.

direction.raw_text: Camera follows Homer into the Worthington house where, from the front hall, he sees Olive and Candy (in profile) sitting on the couch. We can't see who's talking, nor do we recognize the voice. As Homer comes into the living room, we see MAJOR WINSLOW sitting in a chair (also in profile), talking to Olive and Candy. Major Winslow is a smooth, handsome well-briefed officer in the casualty branch of the Army Air Corps; he's done his homework, but he's not all business. He's painfully aware of the delicate nature of his report.

dialogue.raw_text: When the plane was hit, the crew chief and the radioman jumped close together. The copilot jumped third. All on Captain Worthington's orders-- the captain was still flying the plane. None of the men of the ground could see the sky--that's how thick the jungle was. They never saw the plane crash--they never *heard* it crash. They never saw Captain Worthington's parachute, either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why was he missing for twenty days?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because the crew thought he'd gone down with the plane. They were hospitalized for almost a week in China before they were flown back to India. It wasn't until that they sorted through their gear...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who cares about their *gear*?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Three men jumped from the plane, but they had four compasses with them. One of the crew jumped with Captain Worthington's compass.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was in Burma for twenty days without a compass?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He followed the Irrawaddy River, all the way to Rangoon. Somehow he managed to avoid the Japs, but not the mosquitoes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then it's malaria?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's encephalitis B. He's recovering at Mount Lavinia Hospital, Ceylon. (pause) Uh... Captain Worthington is paralyzed. (Olive gasps) Waist down. He won't walk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Olive) I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (asks the major) There are no autonomic effects, are there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No autonomic effects... that's correct.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When will he be home, Major?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Four weeks or so, right around Halloween.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer and the men load crates of apple jelly onto a truck. The mood is solemn; they work with tired focus. Candy drives up. The men are evasive with her; they find a reason to work across the mart. Candy walks to Homer, stands next to him. They say nothing for a moment, until Candy breaks the silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy looks away; she can't think of what to say. She shoves her hands into her pockets, finds a letter there, which she hands to Homer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer looks at the letter from St. Cloud's; he puts it unopened in his pocket without a second thought. Candy can't let things end there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy looks surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy can only stare straight ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A tear rolls down Candy's cheek, Homer wipes it away; then he stops touching her and looks off into the quiet orchards.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think she'll be all right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She knows how to take care of herself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This came for you a couple of days ago. Olive asked me to bring it. With everything happening, I guess she forgot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know you don't think much of being needed, or of me for that matter...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry for what I said about Wally needing you. It was... unnecessary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I'm the one who should be sorry. You have every right to be angry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. You warned me. I didn't listen, but you warned me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You told me you weren't any good at being alone. (pause) You told Wally, too. Right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (relenting) He's going to be fine, Wally's going to be fine. I know he is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The pickers lie in their beds, smoking. Homer is undressing. He pulls the letter out of his pocket and sits down on his bed. Homer opens the letter without enthusiasm and begins to read.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Dear Homer, I am writing to tell you about Wilbur.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Music is playing on the old phonograph as an exhausted Larch gives himself ether.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edna is getting the girls ready for bed. Music continues Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larch has twisted himself on the narrow bed so that his face is unusually close to the windowsill, and when the ether cone starts to fall off his face--and his slack hand trails down, off the side of the bed--the cone becomes caught against the windowsill. He tries to turn his face away from the cone, but he presses his face into the sill--thus holding the ether-soaked cone over his mouth and nose. His hands twitch, he's trying to wake up; the hand that holds the ether bottle lets the bottle fall. The bottle shatters against the sill; the ether spreads, running red with blood from a cut on Dr. Larch's hand or finger. Music continues Over. It's a funeral.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Buster is bringing in the wood as the music plays Over. Buster smells the spilled ether. He heads toward the dispensary, sniffing. Camera follows him into the dispensary. In the dispensary: Buster approaches Larch's ether-bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He drops the armload of wood and runs for help.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Larch? Dr. Larch?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Angela enters. She feels for Larch's pulse; Larch is dead. Angela opens a window. She pull's Larch's body away from the windowsill. Buster joins her on the bed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I can assure you that the overdose was entirely accidental.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer finishes reading the letter; he puts it down, gets up, and walks to a window. He stares into the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer wipes a tear off his cheek.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Let us be happy for Dr. Larch. Dr. Larch has found a family.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Good night, Dr. Larch! Good night, Dr. Larch! Good night, Dr. Larch!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The truck is packed for the long trip south; it passes by the packing house, which looks closed for the season. No one else is about. Muddy is driving slowly, his arm out the open window. In the back, huddled among their belongings, are Peaches and Hero (on one side) and Homer (on the other). The pickers are trying to draw Homer into their conversation, while Homer is giving the apple farm a good-bye look. He has made up his mind about something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer just smiles and shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You ever see a palm tree, Homer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He ain't never been outta Maine!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ain't you sick of pine trees, Homer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As the pickers' truck drives past, Homer is on the side of the truck nearest the Worthington house and driveway; he sees Olive and Candy and Ray helping Wally out of the car and into a wheelchair. A NURSE stands by. Wally is wearing what appears to be an oversized officer's coat or flight jacket, his face looking small in the overlarge clothes. He can't move his legs at all, and his mouth is drawn into a tight-lipped smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Olive is dissolved in tears. Candy is sobbing; she kisses Wally, without ceasing, while he haltingly touches her face, her hair. In the truck the smile is gone from Homer's face. He shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This makes all the pickers laugh, but Homer just smiles and shakes his head. He watches the Worthington house disappear from view.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Let me tell you somethin' about Florida, Homer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) The Sunshine State!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) It's so nice 'n' warm down there, you can pick them grapefruits and oranges *naked*, if you want to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, guys... I'd like to go with you. But I've got to move on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, well... you could move on with *us*, man! You could move on somewhere *warm*!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Homer, stayin' in Maine ain't movin' on!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MOVING TRAIN - PASSENGER CAR - NIGHT A CONDUCTOR, taking tickets, comes to Homer, who is better dressed than we've ever seen him; he is looking at his sober reflection in the black window-glass of the night train when the conductor gets his attention. When the conductor moves on, Homer takes Angela's letter out of his breast pocket; he skips ahead to the end.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Dr. Larch often wondered how the world was treating you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOUD'S - GRAVEYARD - AFTERNOON ANGELA (V.O.) He talked a lot about you, hoping you would be of use, whatever you were up to. Angela and Buster and Mary Agnes and Edna carry Larch's coffin; they set it down by the raw hole. The pile of fresh dirt stands out against the new snow; the hole is black against the new white.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the wheelbarrow with the gravestone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) "Oh, Lord, support us all the day long..."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...until the shadows lengthen and the evening comes, and the busy world is hushed, and the fever of life is over, and our work is done."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see the faces of the girls praying for Larch (Mary Agnes, too) as Edna finishes her favorite prayer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: "Then, in Thy mercy grant us a safe lodging, and a holy rest, and peace at the last."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MOVING TRAIN - PASSENGER CAR - NIGHT Camera closes on Homer, sleeping to the sound of the rocking train. Angela's letter lies in his lap.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Amen! Amen! Amen!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOUD'S - TRAIN STATION - EARLY MORNING The train stops, blowing snow. Homer steps off the train carrying a suitcase and Dr. Larch's bag. The disapproving stationmaster is still disapproving. Music plays Over, something triumphant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOUD'S - THE HILL - EARLY MORNING Homer makes his way up the hill toward the orphanage. Music Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edna is breaking up fights; this time, instead of fighting over snowballs, the orphans are fighting over their pumpkins. Suddenly Homer tops the brow of the hill and they all see him. Buster is the first to catch sight of Homer; he runs toward him. Mary Agnes also sees Homer; she immediately turns away and runs inside. Music FADES OUT Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary Agnes crashes into the bathroom and stumbles up to the mirror; she starts to fix herself up with shaking hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone has heard the news; they come on the run. The children flock around Homer, hugging him. Homer takes Angela and Edna in his arms. Mary Agnes joins the group. Homer takes in how changed, how attractive she is. They smile awkwardly at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer's suitcase is open on the bed; we see Homer's hands as he begins to unpack. Smaller hands reach in and root through the clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curly continues his search. Homer thinks for a second; then reaches into his pocket and pulls out the piece of pale-green glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer hands the piece of glass to Curly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curly is duly impressed; he walks away to examine his new treasure. Homer continues unpacking. He pulls his X ray out and puts it aside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer turns to see Buster, Mary Agnes, Angela, and Edna in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer smiles; he nods. Angela and Mary Agnes start to put Homer's things back in his bag. Edna picks up the X ray and looks at it with a somber expression.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer is stunned; he puts his hand to his heart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer takes that in; he nods. Mary Agnes touches him sympathetically.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Did you bring something for me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what? I did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's from the ocean. It's for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We made up a room for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wouldn't you be more comfortable by yourself?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Homer, do you know what this is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. It's my heart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes her head) Actually, it's Fuzzy's. There's nothing wrong with your heart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuzzy's?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Larch wanted to keep you out of the war, Homer--that's why he did it. That's why he told you it was yours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think he worried about his own heart. He said it would never stand up to Homer Wells going off to war.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Homer looks at his fake diplomas; they are now framed and hanging on the office wall. Homer surveys the office, as if for the first time; he sits down in the desk chair, as if slowly getting used to his new position.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer reads to the boys from "David Copperfield". While his voice is strong--positive, optimistic, certainly reassuring to the boys--there is in the conclusion of the chapter something that distracts him. He seems to hesitate; he misses a line or two, and perhaps he purposely skips one or two others. (Possibly Homer's eyes wander ahead, to the title of the next chapter: "I Make Another Beginning.")
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer stops and looks at the boys' faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Homer puts out the lights and leaves the boys in the familiar semi-darkness. Seconds, later, the closed door to the hall is flung open, flooding the room with light from the hall, and Homer, dressed in his long white laboratory coat and looking every inch the doctor, delivers his best imitation of Larch's popular blessing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On Copperfield and Steerforth and Curly as the door to the hall is closed and semi-darkness prevails in the room again. Copperfield, smiling, shuts his eyes. After a second, the wide-eyed Steerforth shuts his eyes, too. Then Curly. The last to close his eyes is Buster.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: "Thus I began my new life, in a new name, and with everything new about me... I felt... like one in a dream... The remembrance of that life is fraught with so much... want of hope... Whether it lasted for a year, or more, or less, I do not know. I only know that it was, and ceased to be; and... there I leave it."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happens next?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's tomorrow, Curly. Let's mot give the story away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good night, you Princes of Maine! You Kings of New England!
dialogue.name: dialogue
